title: Liverpool and New Balance could learn verdict of bitter court battle by FRIDAY
text:
A verdict in the bitter commercial dispute between Liverpool and their kit sponsor New Balance may be delivered on Friday, following the conclusion of a three-day trial.

Closing arguments from both parties focused predominantly on whether New Balance's offer to match the £30m deal put forward by Nike this summer was made in 'good faith', whether Nike's promise of marketing initiatives was 'measurable and matchable' and what remedies were appropriate in the case.

Liverpool's counsel Guy Morpuss QC argued in the Commercial Court yesterday (Tues) that New Balance had been 'reckless in the extreme' in collating the figures on which their offer of stocking 'Liverpool licensed products' in 6,000 global retail outlets was based.

Liverpool and kit supplier New Balance are in Commercial Court over a contractual dispute

American brand Nike put forward a £30m bid in the summer to manufacture Liverpool's kit

He further said that a remedy of 'specific performance' - which would bind the parties together in a new contract - would be unwise because they are 'not getting on'.

Yet New Balance, represented by Daniel Oudkerk QC, attested that it 'did not wilfully offer a match which it knew that it could not supply or which it did not in fact intend to supply' and said specific performance was appropriate.

At the conclusion of the trial, Boston-based New Balance requested a judgement on Friday, saying they have ‘multi-million pound’ payments due to factories that day.

Mr Justice Teare said that 'novel points' had been raised by both parties in their closing submissions, which may delay his judgement.
description: LAURA LAMBERT AT COMMERCIAL COURT: Mr Justice Teare said that 'novel points' had been raised by both parties in their closing submissions on Tuesday, which may delay his judgement.
